instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2327: What is 820-2327? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .

threads.title: ​[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2327</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - old board
threads.message:
No water damage, just stop work.

<SIGNAL>PPCPUVTT_S0</SIGNAL> - OK
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_MCP</SIGNAL> - NO
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0</SIGNAL> - NO
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - OK
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0_R</SIGNAL> - NO
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - NO
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> - OK
<SIGNAL>PP5VRT_S0</SIGNAL> - OK,
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - OK
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> - OK

- The CPU/GPU get warm
- No Light on the USB mouse
- Have Green Light
- THE FAN DONT WORKs, BUT I HAVE 5V PIN1
- Short to Ground on L7400 34.2 ohm

threads.message: This makes no sense. You can't have no 3v then 3v. And there is no short to ground when there's 34 ohms on a CPU vcore line. This just makes no sense.

threads.title: ​[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2327</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - old board
threads.message:
[USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] Easy to find out my mistake.
When i check <RESISTOR>R7859</RESISTOR>, i plug the charger and i forgot to turn on. This board is not like i5/7. When [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] write back , i check again with the board ON.
I need explain what happen for you guys don't think i'm here just for waste your time.

Can we move forward?
